docTitle.titlePart:
Enhanced Capacity from Non-Stoichiometric
Lithium Iron Silicate, Li 2-2x Fe 1+x SiO 4

byline.docAuthor:
Kinson C. Kam, Anti Liivat, David Ensling,
Torbjörn Gustafsson and Josh Thomas

byline.affiliation:
Ångström Advanced Battery Centre,
Department of Materials Chemistry,
Uppsala University,

front.div:
There has been tremendous interest in recent years in the
development of new cathode materials for high-power
devices. These materials should be environmentally
friendly, low-cost, and provide high power-and energy-
density characteristics, combined with long cycle-life over
a wide-range of temperatures.
Li 2 FeSiO 4 has emerged as a promising new cathode
material for Li-ion battery applications.
1-2 The Li-ion
extraction/re-insertion mechanism in the material has
been shown to involve structural rearrangement as a result
of Li/Fe disorder during the initial charge-discharge cycle
vs. Li/Li
+ . This behaviour is supported by cyclic
voltammetry measurements. Subsequent work on these
orthosilicate materials involving Mn and Co have also
exhibited electrochemical activity with variable levels of
performance.
4-5
In our efforts to optimize the utilization of lithium in the
formula unit and to better understand the properties and
mechanisms in this family of materials, we have focussed
on its non-stoichiometric analogue, Li 2-2x Fe 1+x SiO 4 , with a
theoretical capacity in excess of 200mAh/g. This
corresponds to ~15% increase in capacity.
Precursors for Li 2 FeSiO 4 /C and Li 2-2x Fe 1+x SiO 4 /C were
ball-milled together and then heat treated at elevated
temperature; typically 700°C in a reducing CO/CO 2
atmosphere. X-ray diffraction shows a small volume
expansion with respect to the stoichiometric phase, and
SEM images show the particles obtained to have an
average size of ~100 nm.
